awd_titl_txt: Developing isoscapes and testing lead isotopes of human tooth enamel
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Virginie Renson at the University of Missouri Research Reactor Center (MURR), this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the applicability of lead isotope analysis in human tooth enamel as a means for studying migration in non-temperate climates where preservation of human tissues tends to be poor. This study will also develop lead isotopic baselines across important regions of population growth and human movement. Research will combine methods from archaeometry and environmental sciences to produce universal, detailed tools future researchers can use to identify paleomobility using lead isotopes and tooth enamel. This project will actively involve the collaboration and training of students and the creation and distribution of educational activities for children.

This project will examine the potential use of lead (Pb) isotope signatures in human dentition as a means of studying migration in an important area of population growth and expansion. Lead isotopes (206Pb/204Pb, 207Pb/204Pb, 208Pb/204Pb) have largely been used in archaeological science to trace artifact provenance and are now also being applied with success to the study of human paleomobility in traditionally temperate climates. However, this methodology has yet to be developed in regions where the preservation of prehistoric skeletal material is poor. This postdoctoral research project will address two issues. First, 150 geological and environmental samples will be collected to develop a 20nPb/204Pb isoscape to determine if the geological terrains of this region exhibit distinct Pb isotopoic ratios that can be used in archaeological migration and provenance studies. Second, procedures will be developed from archaeometry and environmental sciences to understand if diagenetic alteration from taphonomic processes, including contamination from modern lead sources, can be systematically detected apart from in vivo lead concentrations in human tooth enamel. Tooth enamel specimens (n = 75) will come from known hubs of migrant activity. Results are expected to advance archaeological migration studies by directly testing the applicability of Pb isotopes in low concentration, low preservation materials and by allowing researchers to study shorter-distance human migration patterns through Pb isoscapes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This NSF SBE Postdoctoral Fellowship assisted Dr. Gina Buckley (PI) in advancing her archaeology career. There were two goals for this research:

1. Test the hypothesis that lead (Pb) isotope analysis in tooth enamel is feasible for prehistoric migration studies in regions where the preservation of skeletal material is poor and modern-day lead contamination in the environment is high. This goal was accomplished by measuring trace elements and isotopic compositions in tooth enamel and comparing the results to regional soils and rocks to determine if in vivo Pb could be measured. Soils underwent sequential soil extractions to isolate the different labile fractions (e.g., carbonates, organics, oxides, and aluminosilicates) to determine the level of diagenetic alteration from the modern environment and measure a natural Pb signature.

2. Build a Pb-isoscape for central Mexico (spatial distribution map characterizing the changes in natural isotopic values over the landscape) with rock and soil samples.

Several significant achievements have come from this fellowship. First, this is the first study to thoroughly investigate the use of Pb-isotope analysis of human remains in the Americas. Results indicate that archaeologists must conduct systematic trace element and isotopic analyses of the local environment, the burial environment, and the skeletal samples to determine the severity of anthropogenic Pb contamination. Publications will provide detailed protocols to achieve these analyses and duplicate results.

Second, this project was a significant training opportunity for Mexican and American students. Two master's students from the Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico (UNAM) in Mexico City assisted in extensive fieldwork surveying and sampling the local terrain for rock, soil, and plant samples. One of those students also completed an internship at the University of Missouri Research Reactor (MURR) under the supervision of PI. During this time, the student received training in enamel, soil, and rock sample processing for isotopic analysis. Several graduate interns and undergrads at MURR also received training in laboratory procedures related to this project. All will be coauthors on all products from this fellowship. In turn, the PI gained invaluable supervisory experience, preparing her for a position that will include mentoring PhD students through their dissertations.

Next, this fellowship opportunity fostered vital collaboration between international and interdisciplinary groups. In the project's initial phases, collaboration was established with Mexican geologists from UNAM in Mexico City. However, the project has grown exponentially and will be the basis of the PI's ongoing career. Researchers from UCLA and Texas A&M have joined forces with the PI to broaden the scope of the original project to now include isoscape development for Sr, C, N, O, and S in this region. This new collaboration has several goals. First, the isoscape project will expand its focus from Mexico to greater Meso- and Central America, including Belize and Guatemala south to Panama. Second, isoscape development will focus on archaeological and forensic applications to better identify human mobility. Third, the expanded project seeks to create a citizen scientist component crucial to its success. The combined region for the isoscape constitutes nearly 2.5 million km2 of landscape, making sampling this area a considerable undertaking. The goal is to foster collaboration with community scientists consisting of local people who will be trained in environmental sample collection. Community-based sample-collecting efforts are a robust avenue for public engagement and provide hands-on learning experiences for archaeological and ecological science enthusiasts.

Finally, a vital outcome of this project has been the development of an outreach program for MURR. Buckley created several opportunities for the Archaeometry Lab at MURR to be involved with community engagement. The Archaeometry Lab worked with the Columbia Art League (CAL) to host a kid's booth at the annual Art in the Park event. This two-day arts event draws over 30,000 people from the surrounding community. Buckley spearheaded this collaboration between MURR and CAL in 2022, and, as a result, will now be an annual outreach opportunity. Buckley also developed partnerships with the Columbia STEM Alliance, a group of teachers dedicated to providing continued education opportunities to elementary and middle school students in the Columbia, Missouri, school district. Buckley participated in several Girls in Stem events to introduce 6-8th grade girls to archaeology. These collaborations have been arranged to continue and grow past Buckley's residency at MURR.

The fellowship was crucial in providing training for the PI that has been essential in building her career. The PI gained experience establishing relationships with international and domestic collaborators and executing highly strategic fieldwork. Within the lab at MURR, the PI gained valuable instrument analysis skills. Buckley was also able to present at several scientific conferences, including the Society for American Archaeology in Chicago (2022), Portland, Oregon (2023), and the Europe Association of Archaeologists (EAA) in Budapest, Hungary (2022). During this fellowship, Buckley also published and submitted first-author papers in archaeology peer-reviewed journals and contributed to several other manuscripts.


Last Modified: 08/28/2023
Modified by: Gina M Buckley

Image
  • Sampling area for central Mexico Pb isoscape (yellow polygon): a)markers of the only isoscape data published to date for this region; b) plant samples collected for this project (n = 450); c) soil samples (n = 66); d) orange are rock samples (n = 22), light green were collected by other projects.
    Gina Buckley
    Creative Commons
    Gina M Buckley
    Isoscape sampling completed for this fellowship
